text:
Hi, this is Julián from MinuteEarth, where it’s 
no secret that we love Pokémon. In case you’re not

that kind of nerd, Pokémon are fictional, 
mostly-adorable creatures that people collect,

train, and battle. The four arguably most-loved 
Pokémon - known as “starters” in the Pokémon

world - are each based on a real-world 
animal, but also have not-so-real-world

abilities. We started wondering whether these 
abilities were actually plausible; after all,

there are some weird adaptations that exist in 
the animal kingdom. So is there a biological

basis for any of these four Pokémon to exist in 
real life? Could you reeeeally catch ‘em all?

First up are bulbasaurs, which closely 
resemble frogs, except for the, well,

plant bulb on their backs. Which sounds weird, 
but the aptly-named decorator crab attaches plants

to its back - and algae and moss grow right on 
all sorts of animals! But bulbasaur’s signature

ability involves actually manipulating 
the vines in its bulb to attack enemies.

And while spring-loaded plants do exist in the 
real world, we don’t know of any animals out there

that can co-opt that behavior for self defense.
OK, so then there’s charmanders, the “lizard

Pokémon,” and notorious flamey-bois. We’re 
not going to rule out the possibility of an

animal evolving a perpetually flaming tail that 
indicates its health but ... come on. Charmander’s

fire-breathing attack on the other hand? Well, 
the, again, aptly-named bombardier beetle

stores a combination of chemicals and enzymes 
in its glands, each of which is inert on its

own – but can combine to explosively shoot acid 
out the beetle’s butt. It’s such an effective

defense that a real lizard has evolved to mimic 
the appearance of similar butt-spraying beetles.

There are also lizards with venom-producing 
glands in their mouths, which could plausibly

adapt to combine the right stuff to get their 
flame-on. And yet, we haven’t discovered

a single flame-producing animal … so far.
Squirtles the turtles, on the other hand,

squirt water out of their mouths – which is much 
more plausible. In fact, sea turtles can expel

excess saltwater out of their mouths and nostrils, 
and if the diamondback terrapin is disturbed while

drinking, it will shoot the water from its throat 
to lighten the load and make a faster getaway.

So we definitely wouldn’t be shell-shocked 
if there were a turtle that evolved to

vomit water at predators in a pinch.
But what of our final contender: pikachus,

the mouse Pokémon? Its most shocking ability is, 
well, its shocking ability. There are real-world

animals that can generate electric shocks - in 
fact, this ability has independently evolved

six times! Some of these animals use small 
electric pulses to communicate or navigate,

but others can generate enough voltage to stun 
or kill their prey or predators. But stunningly,

all the animals that have evolved this 
ability are fish, so hypothetically aquatic

pikachus would be realistic, but pikachus are 
exclusively terrestrial, and air is a muuuuch

worse conductor of electricity than water, 
making this adaptation pretty Farfetch’d.

So, based on real-life biology, one of 
these Pokémon has the very best chance

of existing. That’s why for “most likely to 
actually exist,” squirtle, we choose you!

In some ways, it makes sense that 
our winner is a water Pokémon,

because the water is where some of the 
strangest real-world creatures live,

as I recently rediscovered in the 
CuriosityStream series “Deep Ocean”

narrated by the legendary David Attenborough. Like 
the nautilus they encounter in the first episode,

a deep-sea mollusc that looks a heck of a lot like 
the Pokémon Omanyte. And because CuriosityStream

sponsored this video, you can now get a full year 
of CuriosityStream’s expertly curated shows about

science, history, food, travel, and more for 
just $15 bucks plus you’ll get access to Nebula,

which has exclusive content from your favorite 
educational YouTubers - like us! To get both for

that exclusive price – and support MinuteEarth 
– simply go to curiositystream.com/minuteearth

and use code “minuteearth” at 
checkout. Thanks, CuriosityStream!
